wikipedia_page.main: Thomas Barrett-Lennard (4 October 1788 – 9 June 1856) was a British Whig politician.

response: Robertson used the pages of the Mechanics Magazine to campaign for intellectual property law reform. Starting in 1826, he tried to get a meeting on the topic at the London Mechanics' Institution, which flopped. In 1829 a parliamentary committee on patent reform was set up, after Thomas Barrett Lennard had pushed for an enquiry: Robertson lowered expectations in advance, and was partly justified by a lacklustre and scanty representation of manufacturing interests, with John Farey Jr. providing the bulk of detailed criticism where John Taylor and Marc Brunel showed little knowledge of the system. Lennard's resulting bill ran out of time in the next session of parliament.historyofparliamentonline.org, Barrett Lennard, Thomas (1788–1856), of Belhus, Aveley, Essex and Hyde Park Terrace, Mdx.
